makers.displaymaker: Nike Davies-Okundaye, born 1951, Ogidi, Nigeria; active Lagos and Òṣogbo, Nigeria

texts.textentryhtml: Artist collection, Lagos, Nigeria; [ko gallery, Lagos, Nigeria, 2022]; Princeton University Art Museum, Princeton, NJ, by purchase from the above, October 2022
texts.remarks:
As per credit line. AP.
Revised to reflect acquisition proposal. Perrin Lathrop, 10/3/2024

texts.textentryhtml: Constructed from àdìrẹ textile remnants, Davies-Okundaye’s quilts incorporate a lineage of forms and patterns. The title, Arókọ, which combines the Yorùbá words aró (dye) and kọ (to write), positions the textile as both a repository of knowledge about process and materials and a tool for communicating meaning through the combination of designs. The artist has spoken about the importance of marking her work with her name. She was quoted in her 1995 biography as noting, “Most people who buy crafts do not even know the craftswoman’s name. I put both my name and town on my work, so when visitors come to Òṣogbo and ask for me, they are directed to my house or gallery.”
